Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2014 North American Power Symposium (NAPS), Held at Washington State University, Pullman, WA, September 7-9, 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests funding to subsidize student-related expenses (e.g., travel, registration,
and accommodation) incurred by US students attending the 46th annual North American Power
Symposium (NAPS). NAPS 2014 will be hosted by Washington State University in Pullman, WA,
from September 7 to September 9, 2014. NAPS is a nonprofit event with technical sponsorship
from IEEE and is aimed primarily at a student audience. Traditionally, the overwhelming majority
of papers in NAPS are presented by students. NAPS has been supported by the National Science
Foundation in the past, which has positively influenced student participation. Based on the
attendance trend from previous years, it is anticipated that the subsidy provided through
this grant can significantly increase the number of students participating in NAPS in this
year as well. In addition to providing subsidized accommodation for students, our efforts
to foster and encourage student participation include a comprehensive student program, tours
of nearby attractions, and a student paper competition. Moreover, measures will be taken to
encourage participation of women and underrepresented minorities in NAPS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funds made available through this grant were used to support student activities (social events, food, transportation, and registration subsidy) at 2014 North American Power Symposium (NAPS).

 

NAPS is a nonprofit event with technical sponsorship from IEEE and is aimed primarily at a student audience. Papers in NAPS covers all areas of power engineering including power system operation, performance, protection, control, smart grid, power electronics, and microgrid. NAPS provides a forum for student-faculty-industry interaction and fosters collaboration between US and international students, faculty, and industry.

 

NAPS was held on the campus of Washington State University (WSU) in Pullman, WA, USA, during September 7-9, 2014. This was the first time that WSU hosted NAPS. About 229 participants, out of whom 151 (66%) were students, engaged in different activities at the symposium. The highlights of the program included a reception (Sunday evening), undergraduate poster presentation (Sunday evening), Gala dinner (Sunday evening), several social outing for students (Sunday and Tuesday evening), tours of WSU labs, tours of SEL, a best presentation contest, an undergraduate poster competition, and four panels by industry and academia leaders. The topics of the panels were “smart grid in a societal context,” “Northwest smart grid projects,” “synchrophasor applications,” and “cyberphysical systems.” A total of 150 papers were presented during the symposium; these papers are available on IEEEXplore.

 

Free accommodation (in a room shared with one/two other students of the same gender) was provided for about 80 graduate and undergraduate student participants who had applied through the advertised application form and provided the required information. Out of these students, 8 were Hispanic/Latino, 4 were Black or African American, and 15 were female. Undergraduate students were additionally provided with a travel subsidy of $300.
